metadata.title: Carbon Nanomaterials in Different Dimensions for Electrochemical Energy Storage

sections.text:
P R O G R ES S R EP O R T
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (1 of 21) 1600278wileyonlinelibrary.com
Carbon Nanomaterials in Different Dimensions for Electrochemical Energy Storage
Jiangfeng Ni and Yan Li*
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201600278
In spite of an ongoing advancement, current popular EES systems including Li-ion batteries (LIBs), supercapacitors (SCs), and redox flow cells (RFCs) are limited by severe performance challenges of electrode materials in terms of low energy and power density as well as short durability. To mitigate the issues, carbon nanomaterials could be introduced to these EES systems, taking advantage of their unique geometry, excellent conductivity, large surface area, and intrinsic flexibility. Numerous carbon nanomaterial based EES systems, where carbon nanomaterials are adopted as either conducting additive or active electrode, have been developed and demonstrated appealing energy and power features. With the capability to
enhance the structural and electrochemical properties of electrodes, carbon nanomaterials and their derivatives offer a wide range of possibilities to design advanced EES devices that can meet our growing energy and power demands in the future.
A number of reviews have been published in the past few years on the application of carbon nanomaterials in EES.[5–8] However, this area is so active and new works accumulate very quickly. Therefore, it is helpful to update the new designs and outcomes. This progress report will summarize the most exciting recent (from the year 2010 onwards) advances in the application of carbon nanomaterials with different dimensions, i.e., 0D fullerene, 1D CNT, 2D graphene, and 3D assemblies of CNT and graphene, in EES systems, and highlight the new trends in the field. Besides the repetitively reviewed LIBs and SCs, this work will also deal with another important system, the RFC, which has been rejuvenated recently and is becoming increasingly vital for large scale energy storage. The recent EES applications of carbon nanomaterials will be discussed based on their dimensions.

sections.heading: 1.1. Structure and Properties of Various Nanostructured Carbon
sections.text: Fullerenes, CNTs, and graphene all present conjugated π electron systems. The unique electronic configuration combined with geometric structure endows them with extraordinary properties, which make them superior to their competitors for specific applications such as EES.

sections.heading: 1.1.1. 0D Fullerenes
sections.text:
Fullerene normally has a hollow sphere or ellipsoid shape. Specifically, C60 has a cage-like fused-ring structure (truncated
Carbon nanomaterials including fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, graphene, and their assemblies represent a unique type of materials in diverse formats and dimensions. They feature a large surface area, superior conductivity, fast charge transport, and intrinsic stability, which are essentially required for vari ous electrochemical energy storage (EES) systems such as Li-ion batteries, supercapacitors, and redox flow cells. The scaled-up and reliable production and assembly of carbon nanomaterials is a prerequisite for the development of carbon nanomaterial-based EES devices. In this progress report, the preparation of carbon nanostructures and the state-of-the-art applications of carbon nanomaterials with different dimensions in versatile EES systems are summarized. The importance of the synergetic effect induced by interactions between nanocarbons and active electrode species is highlighted. The main challenges and prospects in this field are also discussed.

Introduction
Since the discovery of C60 in 1985,[1] a new family of carbon allotropes − nanostructured carbon materials or so-called carbon nanomaterials, began to get on the stage and have received tremendous attention in the past three decades. Fullerene, carbon nanotube (CNT),[2,3] and graphene[4] are well known zero-, one- and two- dimensional (0D, 1D, 2D) carbon nanomaterials. Assembly of CNTs and graphene leads to unique three-dimensional carbon nanomaterials (denoted as 3D nanocarbon). Their unique structures (Figure 1) endow them with fantastic properties that have great potentials in many important fields. Recently, the application of carbon nanomaterials in energy production and storage has been a research topic of high priority and has already been shown to be very promising.
Electrochemical energy storage (EES) plays an increasingly critical role in our daily life and in our energy-intensive society.

icosahedron), resembling a soccer ball.[1] It is made of twenty hexagons and twelve pentagons, with a carbon atom at each vertex of each polygon and a bond along each polygon edge. The van der Waals diameter of a C60 molecule is about 1.1 nm in a single crystal, while the nucleus to nucleus diameter of a C60 molecule is about 0.71 nm. Extensive research on fullerene started from 1990, when Kratschmer et al. reported a facile way towards scalable produce of C60 by evaporating graphite electrode in helium atmosphere.[9] Due to the spherical cage structures and the presence of full π-electrons on the surface, fullerenes exhibit numerous fascinating properties that have particular potential for energy-related areas. Specifically, fullerenes and their derivatives are good electron acceptors. They can reversibly accept electrons, and donate them under certain conditions.[10] Fullerenes also reveal rich oxidation and reduction characteristics, which bring about interesting electrochemical properties.

sections.heading: 1.1.2. 1D Carbon Nanotubes
sections.text:
CNTs have a tubular structure, and show a much high lengthto-diameter ratio, typically several nanometers in diameter and many micrometers in length.[2,3] Ultralong CNTs up to 550 mm have been produced recently with a floating chemical vapor deposition process.[11] CNTs are categorized as singlewalled CNTs (SWNTs) and multi-walled CNTs (MWNTs). Both nanotubes often naturally align themselves into “ropes” held together by van der Waals forces, more specifically, π–π stacking. A SWNT is made out of a seamlessly rolled single graphite layer, which is now widely known as graphene, with a diameter of nano meters, normally 1–2 nm. SWNT can be either metallic or semi-conducting, depending on their wrapping angles.[12] MWNT is composed of coaxial graphene tubules that are spaced 0.34 nm apart, with diameters ranging from several to hundreds of nanometers. Unlike SWNTs, MWNTs usually behave like zero-gap metals, and their specific surface area is generally less than that of the SWNTs.
Both SWNTs and MWNTs share features of extremely high electrical conductivity (up to 5000 S cm−1 for metallic SWNTs),
remarkable charge transport mobility (> 100 000 cm2 V−1 s−1), robust thermal stability and conductivty,[13,14] and a large theoretical specific surface area (1315 m2 g−1 for SWNTs).[15] These features make them ideal substances for electrochemical potentiality, which naturally requires efficient movement of charge carriers as well as structural robustness. At certain conditions, CNTs also show rich chemical activities,[16] which are useful for tuning the structure and properties of CNTs to meet special demand.[17] Other possibilities to mediate the scope of their properties include chemical functionalization, and covalent and non-covalent modification of the CNTs.[18] By such approaches, either electronic or surface properties of the tubes can be carefully tailored, which is a key point for materials applied in energy storage devices. Due to their unique electronic, mechanical and structural properties, and massive and controlled synthesis at low cost,[19–21] CNTs have captured immense attention in recent years for commercial availability. They are extremely promising for applications in massive fields such as electronics, catalysis, sensing,[22] and energy storage in particular.[23]

sections.heading: 1.1.3. 2D Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene, a 2D crystal of pure carbon, is the thinnest and strongest substance known to science.[24] Graphene can be described as a one-atom thick layer of graphite, and is the fundamental structural element of other allotropes (see Figure 1).[25] It can be wrapped up into 0D fullerenes, rolled into 1D CNTs or stacked into 3D graphite. It can also be considered as an indefinitely large aromatic molecule, the limiting case of the family of flat polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. In nature, 2D graphenes can exist in single, double and few (three to nine) layers, which are distinguished as three different types.
Similar to CNT, graphene is strong, light, nearly transparent and an excellent conductor of heat and electricity. Experimental results from transport measurements show that graphene has a remarkably high electron mobility at room temperature, with reported values in excess of 15 000 cm2 V−1 s−1.[26] In addition to its exotic electronic properties, graphene exhibits unusually high intrinsic thermal

conductivity, up to ≈5 × 103 W m−1 K−1 at room temperature, which even surpasses the values of CNTs or diamonds.[27] Moreover, graphene appeared to be one of the strongest materials, with a Young’s modulus of 1 TPa.[28] More importantly, although bulk graphite is very stable, graphene is chemically the most reactive form of carbon, owing to the high reactivity of lateral carbon atoms. Moreover, diverse types of defects within the sheet, which are very common, increase the chemical reactivity.[29] Because of excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, huge surface area, unique heterogeneous electron transfer, and remarkable mechanical strength, graphene has been utilized beneficially as an appealing material for energy technologies and particularly in EES.[5]
Graphene can be fabricated by chemical or electrochemical reduction of graphene oxide (GO).[30] The product is usually called reduced graphene oxide (rGO). The rGO naturally suffers from a low quality compared to graphene prepared by other methods, which is principally due to the incomplete removal of functional groups incorporated into GO and the introduction of sp3 carbons.[31] Despite such limitations, rGO allows the elaborate alteration of the electronic and surface properties, through which new functions can be incorporated that cannot otherwise be acquired by pristine graphene. For brevity, graphene, rGO and GO are all referred to as graphene-related material in this work.

sections.heading: 1.1.4. 3D Nanocarbon
sections.text:
In contrast to CNT and graphene that extend the dimensions only along one and two directions, respectively, 3D carbon represents nanostructured carbon materials developed in all dimensions. Other than the conventional 3D carbon nanomaterials, such as mesoporous carbon and activated carbon,[32] in this progress report, we will focus on a prospective new type of 3D nanocarbons, assemblies of CNTs and graphene. CNTbased 3D nanocarbons include vertically aligned CNT (VACNT) arrays,[33] sponge,[34] foams,[35] etc., while 3D nanocarbons based on graphene consist of graphene arrays,[36] graphene foam,[37] and vertically oriented graphene nanosheets,[38] etc. Graphene scrolls that are formed by rolling a graphene sheet to form a helical structure can be regarded as 1D nanocarbon, which has a hybrid structure between that of graphene and carbon nanotubes.[39–41]
Generally, 3D nanocarbons can maintain all the extraordinary nanoscale properties of individual CNT and graphene components such as excellent conductivity, robust charge transport, large surface area, and superb stability. In addition, they show some new functions endowed by the assembly and organization of the components. These functions include hierarchical porous channels, 3D structural stability, and reduced junction contact resistance. The features are particularly important for flexible applications, which require combined electrical and mechanical functionality. Therefore, it is scientifically and technologically essential to design and optimization of 3D carbon-based nano structures
for ESS applications.

sections.heading: 1.2. Electrochemical Energy Storage: Importance and Reliance on Carbon Nanomaterials
1.2.1. Electrochemical Energy Storage: Introduction and Status
sections.text:
Energy storage is now critical to so many aspects of our daily life. It also allows us to balance the supply and demand of energy to run the world. Today’s energy storage systems can be broadly categorized as mechanical, electrical, chemical, biological and thermal. Among such available systems, EES is probably the most promising one due to its versatility and broad potential.[42]
EES is a technology that can meet the needs of various users and be utilized in diverse fields at home and in industry, such as our increasing demand for portable electronics and electricity-driven vehicles, as well as in smart grids that use renewable energy. A number of EES technologies are potential candidates for supporting the above needs. Among them, the LIBs, SCs, and RFCs (Figure 2) are of particular importance,[43] due to the high energy or power density, large flexibility, environmental benignity, technical maturity, and maintenancefree nature. LIBs and RFCs rely on the conversion of chemical energy into electrical energy, while SCs are based on the separation of chemically charged species at an electrified interface between a solid electrode and an electrolyte.[44] As shown in Table 1, each type of system provides a different combination of power density, energy density, efficiency, and cost, serving versatile demands.
Recently, demand for high efficiency EES has soared in every aspect of our life. For example, we use cellular phones for communication and iPads for entertainment, the performance of which has severely been limited by the battery component. In addition, the surge in varied electric vehicles requires sufficient and efficient energy storage with higher energy and power density.[45] It is estimated that there were over 380 000 highwaycapable EVs and utilities worldwide by the end of 2013, up from more than 180 000 units in 2012. The global sale of plug-in electric vehicles is predicted to be 700 000 by the end of 2014, which is a significant growth of 86% versus 2013.
Moreover, environmental concerns have led to a desire to use substantial amounts of renewable energy instead of fossil-fired power stations in recent years. According to statistics, renewable energy such as wind, solar, geothermal, hydro and biofuels are growing rapidly, and provide 18% of electricity generation worldwide in today’s energy consumption.[42] As wind power and solar power sources have unstable outputs, power supply to the entire electrical networks could become unstable. Therefore, the power supplied by renewable energy sources presents a variety of challenges. To overcome such challenges, it is eagerly

sections.heading: 1.2.2. Potential of Carbon Nanomaterials for Electrochemical Energy Storage
sections.text:
Fullerenes, CNTs, graphene, and 3D nanocarbons are ideal candidates for the above-discussed EES systems. Their potential is strongly associated with their merits such as unique structures, stability, and peculiar electric and mechanical properties.[6]
0D fullerenes show intriguing electrochemical reactivity, acting as either electron donor or acceptor depending on the potential. Fullerenes can also be an ideal coating for electrodes in rechargeable batteries. In this case, it acts as a mediate agent to conveniently tune the structure and surface passivation film of electrodes, leading to improved stability.
1D CNTs are of excellent conductivity, rich porosity, and structural flexibility. These characteristics are recognized as essential components of high power EES systems when CNTs serve as conductive additives. For example, a mixture of CNTs and active carbon powder can serve as high-performance electrodes for batteries, and metal oxides supported on CNTs are ideal electrodes for capacitors bearing superb power output. Moreover, they are superior electrodes for flexible, transparent energy storage devices, featuring high energy density with long durability. Furthermore, these properties could be further tailored via certain surface activation or functionalization.
2D graphene materials have shown increasingly importance recently in EES applications. They have extraordinary properties of strength, flexibility, and electrical conductivity. These unique attributes have begun to be utilized in EESs with astonishing outcomes compared with current devices. Specifically, graphene and rGO are superior in conductivity enhancement of the electrode composites, while GO, which is rich in surface functional groups, possesses the potential for fast surface adsorption and desorption reactions, as required for SCs.
In contrast to the great efforts dedicated to 0D, 1D, and 2D nanocarbon materials, research and development of the 3D nanocarbon is a relatively new journey. Due to the ordered structure and well-developed porosity, 3D nanocarbon has a high surface area while maintaining most of the dimensional properties of CNT and graphene. They are hardly bundled or folded and barely plagued by the dispersion issue as 1D and 2D nanocarbons are.[47] Therefore, the 3D nanocarbons hold
considerable potential for EES applications, and often outperform 1D CNT and 2D graphene components in many aspects.[5] For instance, 3D nanocarbon foam has a high surface area due to its porous nature, giving it a high electrochemical capacitance. 3D nanocarbon foam grown directly on metal has good electrical contact with the substrate, further enhancing its performances. In addition, the 3D nanocarbon foam can serve as high-performance current collector for batteries.
Next, we will summarize the state-of-theart applications of 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D carbon nanomaterials in versatile EES systems, with particular emphasis on how nanocarbons interact with active materials to address the specific issue of energy and power of EES systems.

sections.heading: 2. Carbon Nanomaterials for Li-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
LIB is one of the most popular types of rechargeable battery for portable electronics, with one of the best energy densities, almost no memory effect, and only a slow loss of charge when not in use. LIBs are composed of positive (cathode) and negative (anode) electrodes separated by a separator that is filled with electrolytic solution. The positive electrode is often a lithium-containing compound and the negative electrode a carbon material. A binder is used to attach them to a current collector (normally copper foil and aluminum foil). As shown in Figure 2a, when a LIB is connected to an external load, the negative electrode supplies a current of electrons that flow through the load and are accepted by the positive electrode; meanwhile Li+ ions are extracted from the negative host matrix and inserted into positive electrode materials via the internal electrolyte solution.[44]
Currently, LIBs usually adopt a composite electrode sheet, which consists of a carbon additive, to ensure a good electron percolation. The popular additive is graphite and carbon nanoparticles, which are difficult to process and show poor percolation effect. By contrast, carbon nanomaterials such as CNTs, graphenes, and 3D nanocarbons are flexible and porous with huge surface area; they would outperform the conventional carbon materials when used as conductive additives in LIBs.[48] Moreover, hybrids of nanocarbons and active materials integrated by chemical binding rather than physical mixing may be used as bind-free electrodes, providing greater energy density and durability. In addition to conducting additives, these carbon nanomaterials by themselves are promising electrodes for both LIBs and SCs, offering a wider energy voltage, higher power capability and better safety compared with to conventional electrodes.

sections.heading: 2.1. CNTs and Hybrids for Li-Ion Batteries
2.1.1. 1D CNTs
sections.text:
CNTs have been proved to be high-performance 1D electrode materials for LIBs, owing to their unique 1D structure, robust

mechanical strength, high electronic conductivity, and fast charge transport ability.[49,50] The electrochemical response of CNTs towards Li is strongly dependent on the kind and shape of the tubes. Reversible capacities from 350 to 680 mAh g−1 are often observed,[51] surpassing that of commercialized graphite anode of 372 mAh g−1. In situ XRD experiments indicate that the Li reaction with nanotubes proceeds by an actual ion insertion/extraction process, but Li staging in distinct sites of CNTs has not been confirmed, due to the lack of a potential plateau. The capacity of CNTs can be further increased to 1000 mAh g−1, if nanotubes are subjected to chemical treatments such as chemical etching and nitrogen doping.[52,53] These treatments introduce vast defects in the wall of nanotubes, which provide additional sites for Li ion adsorption and contribute to capacity improvement.
Conventional electrodes in LIBs usually consist of polymer binders other than active materials. The binder maintains the structural integrity of the composite electrode, but increases the resistance due to its insulating nature. As a result, it is highly desirable to fabricate binder-free CNT electrodes because of the ease of handling, favorable mechanical properties and excellent conductivity. This target can be achieved by assembling freestanding CNT films, which have been demonstrated by Chew and co-workers.[54] They dispersed CNT samples into aqueous solution of 1 wt% Triton X-100 surfactant. A uniform film was then obtained by vacuum filtering the homogeneous suspension through a porous polyvinylidene fluoride membrane. The as-prepared CNT films exhibited a high and robust electrochemical activity towards Li storage, discharging a capacity of 175 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 10 C.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. 1D CNT Hybrids
sections.text:
Despite a high capacity, 1D CNTs have not readily hit the market due to severely irreversible capacity loss. This loss, depending on the type and surface area of CNTs, could account for 70% of the total capacity, which presumably precludes their application in LIBs. On the other hand, they are perfect electrical additives, owing to the high conductivity and excellent flexibility. Importantly, functionalized CNTs possess a strong adhesive ability to combine with other materials, through electrostatic interaction, π–π stacking, hydrophobic effect, etc.[55,56] Hybrids of CNTs and electrode active materials may generate some new properties caused by the cooperative effects between the two types of components. Therefore, much effort has been devoted to constructing composite electrodes containing CNTs and active electrode materials.
Layered LiCoO2, LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2, spinel LiMn2O4, and olivine LiFePO4 are most popular types of cathodes utilized in LIBs at present.[57] At present LiCoO2 dominates the batteries designed for portable devices due to high energy density. The other three offer lower energy density, but longer lifespan and intrinsic safety. Such batteries are widely used for electric tools, medical equipment and power utilizations. Since these materials suffer from poor electrical conductivity, compositing with CNTs could in-principle enhance the electronic conductivity as well as their rate capability.
Many hybrids composed of CNTs and LiCoO2,[58] LiNi0.4 Mn0.4Co0.2O2,[59] LiMn2O4,[60] or olivine[61,62] have been fabricated, and shown good rate and cycling performance as
predicted. For example, Dillon et al. fabricated a SWNT wired LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2 hybrid electrode using a vacuum filtration approach with the assistance of sodium dodecyl sulfate.[59] In the hybrid, SWNTs form flexible networks that seamlessly stick onto the particle surface of LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2, possibly due to charge-transfer between them. This strong surface connectivity ensures the fast diffusion of ions and electrons during cycling, resulting in a robust (120 mAh g−1 at 10 C rate) and sustainable capacity delivery (91% over 500 cycles). This approach is simple, convenient, and effective, but the usage of SWNTs may present a major challenge as the SWNTs remain too expensive and cannot be produced selectively. On the other hand, active material particles can also directly anchor and grow on nanotubes through sol–gel[61] or hydrothermal reactions.[62] The in situ synthesis can afford improved interactions between CNT and active materials. MWNTs are normally adopted for this purpose instead of SWNTs to reduce the cost. We have fabricated CNT-wired LiCo0.5Mn0.5PO4 nanocomposites by a one-pot hydrothermal route.[62] The LiCo0.5Mn0.5PO4-CNT discharged a high capacity of 151 mAh g−1 with an energy density of 620 mWh g–1, which is 17% greater than that of the pristine LiCo0.5Mn0.5PO4. This nanocomposite retained 92% of the reversible capacity retention over 30 cycles and delivered 116 mAh g−1 at a rate of 1 C (170 mAh g−1), which was superior to most reports for LiCoPO4 related materials. Of course, when constructing such hybrid structures, controlling the growth of active materials on the surface of CNTs rather than in bulk solution is an unavoidable challenge.
Compared with few cases occurring for the cathode hybrids, there have been vast amount of works on 1D CNT-based composite anodes published in the past few years. The active materials mainly include alloying type such as silicon (Si)[63] and tin (Sn),[64] and conversion type such as metal oxides[65–67] or sulfides.[68,69] These materials show a far greater capacity versus currently commercial graphite anode but are plagued by poor stability during Li cycling. For instance, Cui et al. reported a free-standing CNT-Si hybrid through simple infiltration approach. In such a structure, the CNTs function as a structural reinforcement and also a light-weight current collector, resulting in a 20% energy density increase in the whole battery level.[63]
Many transition metal oxides or sulfides have been developed as anodes for LIBs, taking profit of their high capacity, good safety, and low cost.[70] Nevertheless, two major issues of poor electronic conductivity and drastic volume change upon lithium uptake/release have set a challenge for their use in batteries. By compositing these materials with CNTs, both critical issues could be well mitigated. These materials typically include iron oxides,[71,72] manganese oxides,[73,74] titanium oxides,[75–77] and CuS,[78] due to their abundance, low cost and environmental benignity. It should be admitted that CNTs only electrically percolate a small portion of active electrode particles in these hybrids by nature of point contact. To realize full electrical percolation, we designed and fabricated a strongly coupled Bi2S3@CNT hybrid where Bi2S3 overlayers are tightly anchored onto the surface of nanotubes (Figure 3).[69] The hybrid exhibited a stable and robust Li-storage capacity, retaining 405 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles at a rate of 1 A g−1 and delivering 429 and 376 mAh g−1 at high rates of 2 and 5 A g−1. Alternatively, fully electrical percolation can also be fulfilled by

Very recently, we synthesized CNT-wired MoO3 nanosheets by a hydrothermal reaction followed by controlled reduction in Ar/H2 to form a MoO2 surface layer.[67] As the metallic MoO2 provided nearly full electronic percolation, the composite exhibited much improved Listorage compared with the original MoO3/CNT structure.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. 3D CNTs and Hybrids
sections.text:
Growing 3D CNTs such as VACNT arrays and CNT foams may be an ideal approach towards efficient CNT electrodes.[79] The intrinsic properties of individual nanotubes make the VACNTs ideal candidates for integration in a wide range of devices, particularly in EES systems. VACNT electrodes are also attractive for basic electrochemical evolution as model electrodes due to absence of the binder and conductive agent.[80] However, most VACNTs were grown on insulating silicon or quartz wafers. The transfer of VACNTs to conductive substrate is a prerequisite for energy applications but still challenging. A general strategy to address this challenge involves a two-step process, i.e., sputtering of metal layer onto the top surface of the VACNT array followed by washing out the original substrate (quartz or silicon) with a hydrofluoric acid solution. Welna et al. reported transferring VACNT array from quartz to Ni substrate.[81]
The VACNTs were characterized by a high and stable capacity delivery with excellent rate capability. They exhibit a high capacity of 750 mAh g−1 over 30 cycles, and retain 166 mAh g−1 at an extremely high rate of 26 A g−1. Such a remarkable electrochemical performance is strongly correlated to the alignment of the CNT electrode, which increases the effective surface area of the electrode and facilitates the Li ion diffusion along the axis direction.[82,83] Moreover, the intimate contact between each nanotube and the nickel metal current collector provides a low resistance pathway, allowing for effective connectivity throughout the electrode. Consequently, the aligned CNT assembly can simultaneously achieve both high energy density and robust power output. Nevertheless, as an aligned
CNT array is difficult to produce and handle in a real battery manufacturing environment, more explorations are still needed towards practical utilization in LIBs.
To realize better electrical percolation, combining metal oxides with 3D CNTs is another promising possibility. This can be realized by using CNT array,[65] aligned CNT scaffold,[72] and CNT foam[84] as conductive substrates. The Ajayan group reported MnO2/CNT hybrid coaxial nanotube arrays.[65] Fabrication of the arrays involved template-directed preparation of MoO2 nanotubes, followed by the growth of CNTs using chemical vapor deposition and the coating of Au thin films (≈100 nm). When explored as electrode materials for LIBs, the MnO2/CNT coaxial nanotubes displayed a high reversible capacity of ≈500 mAh g−1.
Recently, the rechargeable Li/S battery has received increasing attention due to its extremely high theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g−1 and energy density of 2600 Wh K g−1. Despite ongoing research over three decades, commercialization of the Li/S battery has not been successful due to the lack of electrical conductivity and poor cycling stability of sulfur electrode.[85] Sulfur alone is a typical insulator, with electronic conductivity on the order of 10−30 S cm−1. Additionally, full reduction of sulfur to lithium sulfide (Li2S) doubles the volume of the original sulfur, causing significant mechanical stresses and rapid capacity decay. Formation of S-CNT composite electrode can finely mitigate the above issues, as recently demonstrated by Peng et al.,[86] Wang et al.,[87] and Kaskel et al.[88] Specifically, S-CNT-PAN ternary hybrids afforded a capacity retention of 96.5% for 100 cycles and high power rate capability up to 7 C.[87] This might provide a prospective direction for future research on sulfur electrode for rechargeable batteries.

sections.heading: 2.2. Graphene Related Materials and Hybrids for Li-Ion Batteries
2.2.1. 2D Graphenes
sections.text:
2D graphene presents many desired properties for LIB applications such as high conductivity and Li-storage capacity. While

conventional graphite only accommodates a maximum of one Li+ ion per six carbon atoms (LiC6 configuration) with a gravimetric capacity of 372 mAh g−1, graphene can double this capacity assuming both sides of graphene sheet can adsorb equal amount of Li ions.
A pioneer work by the Honma group reported that graphene sheet electrodes achieved a Li-storage capacity of 540 mAh g−1. Moreover, the capacity can be significantly raised to 730 or 784 mAh g−1, when CNTs or C60 molecules, respectively, were incorporated to prevent restacking of the graphene sheets.[89] Indeed, restacking of graphene sheets dramatically reduces the active sites for Li ion adsorbing and thereby resulting in a decline in the available capacity.[90] In contrast, formation of structural defects and functional groups in graphene materials could efficiently lift the capacity level by providing additional Li adsorb sites,[91] and facilitate Li ion diffusion on graphene planes.[92] Consequently, the performance of graphene is naturally dependent on the fabrication method. As rGO inevitably contains oxygenated groups and defects, it often achieves superior capacity to those via other approaches, even surpassing the theoretical value (744 mAh g−1) for single-layer graphene.
Chemical doping by heteroatoms provides a feasible strategy to increase the activity of nanocarbon materials as it induces various defects.[93] In this regard, Cheng et al. fabricated N-doped and B-doped rGO materials by thermally reducing GO in NH3 and BCl3 atmosphere, respectively.[94] The doped graphene demonstrated a reversible capacity of about 1000 mAh g−1 at a rate of 50 mA g−1, significantly greater than that of the pristine graphene. More importantly, a high capacity of ≈199 and 235 mAh g−1 at an extremely high rate of 25 A g−1 was obtained for N-doped graphene and B-doped graphene, respectively. This is equal to completing discharge in short time duration of ≈30 s. The high and robust capability endows the doped graphene materials with great potentiality for batteries, although to avoid the usage of hazardous species like NH3 and BCl3 remains a considerable difficulty.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. 2D Graphene Hybrids
sections.text:
Despite a large capacity, the low packing density and sloping voltage render a reduced volumetric energy density, which make graphene less competitive for batteries. To boost the energy density, researchers try to embed various electrode materials into a graphene matrix. In the hybrid structure, the graphene sheets serve as a conducting and flexible support, providing a fast path for electron transport, while the active material particles act as host for Li-storage and spacer to avoid the agglomeration of graphene sheets. By taking advantage of the synergetic effect between the two components, these hybrids afford a high capacity and fast charge transfer capability, opening up new and wide applications for graphene-based batteries.[95,96]
Numerous hybrids consisting of oxide/sulfide and graphene have been explored. Generally, enhanced electrochemical capabilities have been observed versus individual components, regardless of the metal species and the type of interaction between them. Typical binary oxides and sulfides include TiO2,[97,98] Mn3O4,[99] Co3O4,[100] SnO2,[101] SnS2,[102] Sb2S3,[103] and MoS2,[104] which are important candidates for EES but their
low conductivity and poor stability usually necessitate additional conducting phases. Synthesis of oxide/graphene hybrids often involves deposition of metal hydrolysate onto graphene sheets followed by phase transforming to the target products. Dai et al. proposed a “free growth” concept to explain how to control the nucleation and growth of metal hydroxides or oxides selectively on graphene sheets rather than in free solution. They believed that it was critical to use mixture solvents such as DMF-water and ethanol-water to suppress the hydrolysis reaction in free solution. This is because both DMF and ethanol are good solvents in which GO can be well dispersed to avoid aggregation and fully expose the surfaces of the sheets to interact with metal ions and host nanoparticles.[96]
In light of this principle, graphene hybrids consisting of fine Mn3O4[99] and Co3O4[100] nanoparticles (10–30 nm in size) homogeneously anchored on conducting rGO were prepared. When evaluated as an advanced anode material for lithium batteries, both the Mn3O4/graphene and Co3O4/graphene nanocomposites displayed superior Li-storage performance with a large reversible capacity (>900 mAh g−1), stable cyclic performance (negligible capacity fading over tens of cycles), high Coulombic efficiency (above 98%), and good rate capability (retaining 500 mAh g−1 at 500 mA g−1). These results clearly highlight the advantages of anchoring nanoparticles on graphene sheets for the maximum utilization of electrochemically active metal oxide and graphene. In addition, graphene hybrids consisting of ternary metal oxides such as NiCo2O4[105] and ZnCo2O4[106] have also captured increasing interest. Their nanosheet characteristics ensure the perfect coupling between the oxides and the graphene.
Graphene serves as excellent conducting support for olivine materials.[107–110] The latter are appealing cathode candidates for constructing efficient and safe batteries but have long been plagued by their electronically insulating nature.[111] A representative case was demonstrated by Dai et al., as shown in Figure 4.[107] Guided by the “free-growth” principle, they synthesized a mixed phosphate LiMn0.75Fe0.25PO4 nanorods–graphene composite, which exhibited a high capacity level of 155 mAh g−1 at a C/2 rate, and 153, 132, 107 mAh g−1 at 2 C, 20 C, and 50 C, respectively. This outperformed some of the best reported cathode materials with ultrahigh rate capabilities, which may open a new possibility for utilizing intrinsically safe but insulating olivine materials such as LiMnPO4 and LiCoPO4.[112,113]
Alternatively, graphene supported spine LiMn2O4 and layered LiNi0.66Co0.17Mn0.17O2 outperformed the pristine materials in terms of capacity delivery, rate performance and cyclability.[114,115] In recent years, there has been a research trend in combining the sulfur electrode with graphene for Li/S batteries. Dai and Cui et al. designed and prepared a graphene/ sulfur composite material by wrapping poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) coated sulfur particles with mildly oxidized graphene oxide sheets decorated by carbon black nanoparticles.[116] The resulting graphene/sulfur composite showed high and stable specific capacities up to ≈600 mAh g−1 over more than 100 cycles. The authors attributed the modification to the PEG and graphene coating layers, which facilitated electron transport and minimized the dissolution of polysulfides.[117] The combination of graphene and PEG allows researchers to engineer more efficient sulfur electrodes and Li/S batteries. The success of this trial may lead to revolution in the current battery industry.

sections.heading: 2.3. 0D Fullerenes for Li-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
In 1991, Seger et al. evaluated the film electrodes of C60 and C70 fullerenes in propylene carbonate (PC)/lithium perchlorate (LiClO4) electrolyte.[118] They found that the C60 could be electrochemically reduced to C603− by Li with certain reversibility. However, the resultant fulleride anion was appreciably soluble in the electrolyte soluble. This appears to be one of the main reasons for the loss in electroactivity of C60 coated electrodes and consequently denied the feasibility of fullerene electrodes alone for lithium batteries. Nevertheless, recent works have shown that fullerenes can be good coating film for Si anode. The fullerene layer acted as an artificial solid electrolyte interphase, which modified the Li-ion kinetics as well as Si electrode/electrolyte interphase during cycling process.[119,120]
As fullerenes are 0D materials, they do not provide an efficient path for electron transport. As such, 0D fullerenes cannot function as conductive agents in electrodes for LIBs.

sections.heading: 3. Carbon Nanomaterials in Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Due to the urgent need for high-power energy storage systems, much attention has been devoted to SCs in recent years.
SCs, also known as electrochemical capacitors or ultracapacitors, are able to store and deliver energy at relatively high rates.[121] Similar to the structure of conventional capacitors, SCs are constructed from two highly porous electrodes immersed in an electrolyte and separated by a dielectric membrane that allows ions to pass through (see Figure 2b). When applying an external electric field to the device, positive and negative charges accumulate on the surfaces of both electrodes, and ions in the electrolyte solution diffuse across the separator and fill the pores of the electrodes. Hence, a double layer of charges by electrostatic attraction is formed at each electrode. Governed by the same basic principles as capacitors, SCs constructed with high surface area electrodes drastically raise the capacitance and energy. In addition, with a low equivalent series resistance, they can afford a more robust power capability than rechargeable batteries. Furthermore, they are characterized by a virtually indefinite cycle life and charge to discharge energy efficiency close to 100%. As a result, SCs can bridge the gap between the batteries and capacitors, offering an novel approach to meet the increasing power demands for EES.[122]
Apart from activated carbon, which achieves a high capacitance through surface ion adsorption (electrical double layer capacitors, EDLCs), metal oxide and conducting polymers are the other two types of electrode materials suitable for SCs but storing charge mainly by surface Faradaic redox reaction (pseudocapacitors).[123,124] In practice, these two mechanisms can function simultaneously, depending on the nature of the electrode materials and electrolytes. Capacitive performance of these materials is usually presented by their capacitance (C).

Energy storage performance of SCs is given by the maximum energy Emax = (CU2)/2 and maximum power Pmax = U2/(4R), where C is capacitance, U the open-circuit voltage, and R the equivalent series resistance of the capacitor.[125]
Current SCs based on activated carbon can display an energy storage density of 5−7 Wh kg−1 with a cycle life of ≈5000 cycles. This energy is drastically above that of a conventional capacitor but still ≈1/20 of that of an advanced LIB. To satisfy everincreasing energy and power demands, nanocarbon materials have been explored as both electrode and supporting materials for developing high-performance SCs. Vast results have shown that these nanomaterials hold many prominent properties that are particularly adaptive for SCs devices.[126]

sections.heading: 3.1.1. 1D CNT Electrodes
sections.text:
Generally, evaluation of charge storage capability of the electrode materials is represented by their capacitance, which is associated with the electrode/solution interface, more specifically, the accessible surface area to electrolyte (typically, ≈ 20−50 μF cm−2). Having an extremely large surface area and superior electrical conductivity, CNTs alone are excellent electrode material constituting SCs. So far both SWNTs[127] and MWNTs[128] have been intensively explored as electrodes for
SCs and have shown promising features in performance. Their capacitances vary with the type of carbon and its conditions of preparation. SWNT have a very high surface area of 1315 cm2 g−1, and a theoretical capacitance in the range of 260−650 F g−1. However, the measured capacitance values of the CNT electrodes are much lower, varying from 18 to 137 F g−1, which is possibly due to poor accessibility to micropores below a certain size.[128]
CNTs can also be developed into special architectures, which bring out some conceptually-novel SCs that are mainly designed for flexible and printable electronics. Here, we summarize two typical types. One is the fully printable SCs based on CNT thin films. The CNT films can be directly sprayed onto polyethylene therephthalate (PET) substrates[129] or printed onto Xerox paper,[130] possessing a great potential of flexibility. In the former case, suspension of purified SWNTs was sprayed onto PET substrates to form an entangled random network. The resulting CNT films with a thickness of ≈0.6 μm and a sheet resistance of ≈40–50 Ω exhibited a specific capacitance of ≈120 F g−1, which is superior to the thick, free-standing CNT Bucky papers.[33,131] The sheet resistance could be further decreased below 30 Ω when paper was used as substrate. The paper-supported SCs presented a high specific capacitance of
200 F g−1 in sulfuric acid electrolyte, and maintained 70 F g−1 at an extremely high rate of 40 A g−1. Meanwhile the PET-based counterpart only showed a capacitance of less than 50 F g−1. The high performance is probably due to the strong capillary force of porous paper that enables a high contacting surface area between the flexible nanotubes and the paper. This simple architecture with the sole use of printable materials potentially enriches the types of charge storage devices.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. 1D CNT Hybrid Electrodes
sections.text:
CNT electrodes, particularly functionalized CNT electrodes, have exhibited potential for advanced SCs. However, the low yield and high cost render them uncompetitive with current activated carbons. The latter play a predominant role in commercial SC devices due to massive production, high surface area (1000−2000 m2 g−1) and low cost, whereas they frequently suffer from limited electrical conductivity and mechanical strength. One possible strategy to circumvent this difficulty is to fabricate activated carbon and CNT hybrid electrodes. However, incorporating CNTs in composite electrodes is not easy, because CNTs have a strong tendency to form bundles, owing to the extremely high van der Waals attraction between the individual tubes. In an attempt to address this issue, Aurbach and co-workers[132,133] developed a polymer-carbonization route to uniformly disperse CNTs into a carbonized and activated carbon

matrix. The presence of CNTs, even in a portion as little as 1.5%, could lead to an impressive mesoporous structure of the activated matrices, facilitating their electroadsorption/desorption kinetics. Such electrodes afforded a capacity of more than 200 F g−1 in aqueous KOH solutions, and sustained the capacitance for many thousands of cycles. As the method is universal and adaptive for diverse polymeric species and CNTs, it may pave the way for commercial application of CNT-based SCs.
Other than activated carbon, CNTs combined with conducting polymer and/or transition metal oxides also upgrade the charge storage capability to a great extent. Conducting polymers, such as polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), and poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) are all superior electrode materials for SCs due to the fast electrochemical switching and high capacitance level. The main drawback associated with these materials is the poor stability during cycling, owing to structural swelling and mechanical brittleness during doping/de-doping process.[134] CNT can well mitigate the above issue serving as a perfect backbone for a homogenous distribution of polymers. CNTs also improve the charge transfer that enables a high charge/discharge rate.[135–137]
Recently, there has been a growing interest in the composites of CNT and nanostructured materials for SCs by taking advantage of their pseudocapacitance. VN,[138] RuO2,[139] V2O5,[140,141] and Ni3S2[142] are some of the intensively studied pseudocapacitive materials. Among them, VN is particularly attractive for SC applications regarding the excellent electrical conductivity and high specific pseudocapacitance.[143] In a typical work reported by Zhou et al., flexible freestanding mesoporous VN nanowires (MVNNs)/CNT hybrid electrodes were fabricated by a simple vacuum-filtering method
(Figure 5).[138] The freestanding MVNN/CNT hybrid could be used to constructed high performance all-solid-state flexible SCs, sufficiently utilizing the synergistic effects from the high electrochemical performance of MVNNs and the high conductivity and mechanical consolidation of the CNTs. The flexible SCs exhibited a high volume capacitance of 7.9 F cm−3 and energy and power density of 0.54 mWh cm−3 and 0.4 W cm−3 at a current density of 0.025 A cm−3. The exciting results indicate a bright future for the use of the CNT-based hybrids in some conceptually new SCs.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. 3D CNT Hybrid Electrodes
sections.text:
3D CNT electrodes are particularly interesting for SC applications where transport of electron and ion transport should not be limited. 3D CNTs for SCs can be simply fabricated through self-assembly of functionalized MWNTs, using layer-by-layer (LBL) assembly[55] or vacuum-filtration.[144] In a typical LBL process (Figure 6), carboxylated MWNTs and amine-functionalized MWNTs were prepared and assembled onto ITO-coated glass slides alternately by adjusting the pH values of the solutions.[55] The obtained LBL-MWNT electrodes have a density of 0.83 g cm−3, and show a much higher volumetric capacitance of ≈180 F cm−3 in non-aqueous electrolyte. By taking profit of pseudocapacitance of surface oxygen on CNTs efficiently, the energy density can reach ≈200 Wh kg−1 even at a gravimetric power of ≈100 kW kg−1 based on the mass of single electrode, which even approaches the same order of magnitude for the battery materials. However, LBL is tedious process and thus its application has largely been limited in the lab.

The Cui group reported a 3D porous CNT-MnO2 textile framework to efficiently tailor their function in SCs.[145] Such a hybrid allowed a much high MnO2 loading of 8.3 mg cm−2, which led to a high areal capacitance of 2.8 F cm−2. Other hybrid electrodes based on 3D CNTs such as NiCo2O4/CNT core/shell vertically aligned arrays[146] and RuO2/CNT foams[147] have also been elaborately engineered and fabricated. They show greatly enhanced electrochemical properties, remarkably outperforming the bare redox-active materials and the counterparts constructed from freely entangled CNT.

sections.heading: 3.2. Graphene-Related Materials and Hybrids in Supercapacitors
3.2.1. 2D Graphene Electrodes
sections.text:
In analogy with CNT, graphene by itself is a good capacitive material. The high conductivity and exceptionally large specific surface area are two of the key properties of graphene for constructing high-performance SCs. As the intrinsic capacitance of graphene reaches 21 μF cm−2,[148] well defined single-layered graphene nanosheets can afford a double-layer capacitance of

550 F g−1, assuming the entire 2630 m2 g−1 is fully utilized. This is three-fold that of an activated carbon electrode. However, graphene or rGO nanosheets tend to fold and restack together, resulting in micropores with size likely below 1 nm. These micropores are too small for access of electrolyte ions, which leads to a substantial loss of specific capacitance. To achieve a high-performance graphene electrode, it is essential to avoid the severe stacking of graphene sheets and control the pore configuration.
Ruoff and co-workers developed the first graphene-based capacitor, and achieved specific capacitances of 135 and 99 F g−1 in aqueous and organic electrolytes, respectively.[149] Yang and co-workers described the synthesis of graphene sheets by a lowtemperature chemical exfoliation approach. Their graphene afforded the highest specific capacitance of 279 F g−1 in aqueous KOH solutions.[150] The capacitance is highly dependent on the applied electrolyte, and a specific capacitance of 100–250 F g−1 was reported for a curved graphene in various ionic liquid electrolytes.[151] As ionic liquid electrolyte could raise the operation voltage up to 4 V, a high specific energy of 85.6 W h k g−1 was achieved for the SCs based on the curved graphene. This energy density is larger than that of activated carbon SCs and comparable to that of nickel metal hydride batteries but with robust rate capability.
Recently, Ruoff et al. have developed an efficient chemical activation strategy to drastically increase the surface area of exfoliated graphite oxide.[152–154] The resultant rGO materials have abundant mesopores, extremely large surface area (2400−3290 cm2 g−1), and excellent conductivity, which ultimately lead to a superb electrochemical capacitive performance. This carbon material showed a specific capacitance of 166 F g−1 with a voltage range of 3.5 V in the (BMIM BF4)/AN electrolyte, affording a specific energy of 70 Wh kg−1 of the symmetrical SC. More notably, 97% of the capacitance was retained after 10 000 cycles.[152]
Notwithstanding marked advances in graphene based SCs, the mechanism of how the electrolyte ions access the active surface sites of graphene is still unclear. The correlation between the specific area, pore size distribution and the capacitance is also under debate. Therefore, both theoretical and experimental studies on the mechanism of charge storage in graphene materials should be performed to advance their development in SCs.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. 2D Graphene Hybrid Electrodes
sections.text:
There has been growing interest in compositing graphenes with pseudocapacitive materials such as metal oxides and sulfides in recent years.[96,155] Since most of pseudocapacitive materials are electronic insulators, graphene sheets could provide flexible conducting networks for the active materials, allowing fast charge transfer. Meanwhile, the nanostructured oxides or sulfides are able to effectively prevent the aggregation of graphene sheets caused by van der Waals interactions. Consequently, an increase in the available active surface area and an accessible pore for energy storage is often predicted.[156]
A MnO2 nanowire/graphene composite (MGC) can be utilized to construct graphene/MGC asymmetric capacitors that can be cycled reversibly in the high-voltage region of 0–2.0 V in
aqueous electrolyte.[157] They exhibit a superior energy density of 30.4 Wh kg–1, which is much higher than those of symmetric SCs based on graphene/graphene (2.8 Wh kg–1) and MGC/ MGC (5.2 Wh kg–1). In a similar way, a free standing rGO/ MnO2-rGO asymmetric capacitor afforded a higher energy density of 42.6 Wh kg–1, representing a significant step forward in the development of advanced SCs.[158] Guided by the same strategy, Mn3O4/graphene,[99] MoS2/rGO,[159] and RuO2/ graphene hybrid[160] were also explored. The latter afforded a specific capacitance of ≈367 F g–1 (based on the total mass of the hybrid) at a scan rate of 2 mV s–1, and ≈280 F g–1 at a high rate of 40 mV s–1. In all cases, both graphene and rGO offer the added benefit that they help to disperse and stabilize the active material particles via strong chemical interactions. This stable effect is a key for improving power capability and cycle stability of pseudocapacitive materials.
Considerable effort has been devoted to the design and controlled fabrication of nanocarbon hybrid assemblies such as graphene/CNT[161,162] and rGO/activated carbon.[163,164] In these assemblies, graphene or rGO act as a flexible bridge to form a ‘‘plane-to-point’’ conducting network, whereas the CNTs or activated carbon particles sever as spacers between the graphene layers to prevent them from restacking. Consequently, the resulting materials outperform any individual components that constitute to them. Moreover, the graphene/CNT can be further incorporated by metal oxides to form ternary composites, as recently described by Liu and colleagues.[165] Enabled by intensive interaction between graphene, CNT, and oxides, the ternary hybrids were conductive, flexible, robust electrodes, and free of current collectors and binders, which were well adapted for high power and flexible devices. These studies provided a new and facile approach in fabricating cutting-edge SCs.
On the other hand, GO represents an intriguing and interesting nanoscale carbon that may play an important role in energy storage devices including SCs.[166] This is mainly due to their abundant oxygen functional groups tethered on their basal planes and edges, and excellent solubility in water and other solvents. However, the electrochemical performance is often compromised by the poor conductivity, due to severe loss of sp2 domain of carbon in GO. To improve the capacitive function, researchers try to integrate GO with conducting materials such as CNT[166] and conductive polymer PPy.[167] The GO/PPy composite even afforded a much high capacitance of 960 F g−1.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. 3D Graphene and Hybrid Electrodes
sections.text:
There is no doubt that a 3D ordered graphene framework would outperform a 2D counterpart in SCs. This is because the former have a well-controlled pore configuration featured with narrow mesopore size distribution.[168] Besides the graphene framework, 3D graphene can be built by directly growing orientated nanosheets[38] and post assembly to unique hydrogels.[169] By engineering these structures, the geometric profit can be fully utilized. These 3D structures of graphene are often featured with superior charge/discharge properties, which makes them perfectly adapted for advanced SCs.[53]
3D graphene foam[170–172] or graphene-CNT pillared structures[161,173,174] could be ideal conductive support for

© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (13 of 21) 1600278wileyonlinelibrary.com
pseudocapacitive electrodes. The resulting 3D composites often demonstrate performance superior to 2D graphene counterparts. Dong et al. reported 3D graphene/Co3O4 composites where Co3O4 nanowires were incorporated into 3D graphene foam.[170] Such composites afforded a high energy and power density and robust cycling stability, 768 F g–1 at a current density of 10 A g–1, and ≈1100 F g–1 after 500 cycles. In a facile example as shown in Figure 7, Dai et al. reported a grapheneVACNT pillared structure that served as a perfect substrate for Ni(OH)2 pseudocapacitive materials.[173] The resulting Ni(OH)2coated VACNT–graphene electrode could deliver ≈1100 F g–1 for Ni(OH)2 alone and ≈600 F g–1 for the total electrode at a current rate of 22.1 A g–1. More importantly, 96% capacity was retained over 20 000 consecutive cycles, indicative of an excellent long-term electrochemical stability. The energy density of the Ni(OH)2-coated VACNT graphene reached ≈35 Wh kg–1 at a high power density of ≈8 kW kg–1, which is superior to that of Ni(OH)2 composites with CNTs or graphene.[175,176]

sections.heading: 3.3. Fullerenes and Hybrids in Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Although fullerenes exhibit limited battery performance, they are prominent for SC applications due to their high redox activity and large surface areas.[177,178] C60/Pd polymer films displayed a capacitance comparable to those of other SWNT composite film coated electrodes, suggesting a plausible application of this material in developing SCs. Charge storage in the fullerene polymers involved the pseudocapacitor mechanism arising from Faradaic reduction of fullerene.[179] Recently, Lu et al. have successfully grafted conjugated polymer PANI onto fullerene C60 (C60-PANI) through copolymerization of aniline with PPD-functionalized fullerene.[180] The novel C60-PANI hybrid achieved a specific capacity of 776 F g−1 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2, and the specific energy reached 64 Wh kg−1. As the effective loading (2.2 wt%) now is much lower compared
to graphene (44 wt% in graphene/PANI hybrid),[181] the perspective of fullerenes in energy storage fields such as SCs may surpass our common beliefs.

sections.heading: 4. Carbon Nanomaterials for Redox Flow Cell Applications
sections.text:
As schematically illustrated in Figure 2c, a RFC is principally referred to as a rechargeable fuel cell where the electroactive components were dissolved in liquids contained within the system and separated by an ion-exchange membrane. The electrolytes flow through an electrochemical cell that reversibly converts chemical energy directly to electricity or vice versa.[182] In a RFC, the total energy that can be stored depends on the size of the storage tanks, while the system power capability is determined by the size of the stack. This leads to decouplement between their power and energy of the RFCs, which present a prominent merit over LIBs and SCs. RFCs can also be rapidly “recharged” by replacing the electrolyte liquid while simultaneously recovering the spent material. These unique technical merits make RFC a leading solution in providing scalable solution for intelligent, efficient, and capable energy storage.[183]
Among the RFC systems available, such as the all-vanadium, zinc/bromine, and iron/chromium, only all-vanadium RFC (vanadium-RFC) has been commercially tested worldwide. This is because vanadium-RFCs afford higher energy efficiencies with longer durability with respect to other RFCs.[184] These competitive features, of course, are inherited from the unique battery configuration where only the vanadium species are used. This diminishes cross-over contamination of electroactive species and the intrinsic effect of the shunt current.
Currently, carbon materials such as carbon felt, graphite felt, carbon paper, and graphite powder have been investigated as the electrodes for vanadium-RFCs. Among them, 3D structured carbon felt and graphite felt are preferred because

of their enhanced three-dimensional network structures and higher specific surface areas, as well as good conductivity and chemical and electrochemical stability.[185] However, their poor kinetic reversibility towards the electrode reactions poses a barrier towards efficient application of the vanadium-RFCs. Therefore, much attention has been paid to their modification with carbon nanomaterials to enhance electrochemical activities. Of particular interest are the CNTs and graphene. In contrast, the exploration of fullerenes in RFCs application has just started.[186] It is expected that more results will be reported in the near future.

sections.heading: 4.1. Redox Flow Cells Based on CNTs and Derivatives
sections.text:
CNTs have been extensively exploited as electrodes for RFCs due to their high conductivity, catalytic activity, and chemical stability. Both SWNTs[187] and MWNTs[188] were suggested as an electrode reaction catalyst by Li et al. and their performances were investigated for the VO2+/VO2+ redox couple in vanadiumRFCs. The electrochemical activities of the redox couple were remarkably increased by the CNT catalysts over those of modified GC electrodes, suggesting the excellent electro-catalytic activity of CNTs. It is worth pointing out that only CNTs rich in functional groups show striking activity, otherwise they display a rather poor reversibility and activity in the vanadium reaction. The high catalytic effects essentially stem from the surface defects and oxygen functional groups of the CNTs, while the intact nanotubes merely provide a fast channel for electron transport.[187]
Functionalization provides a powerful route to improve the catalytic activity of CNTs for RFC reactions. The oxygen functional groups facilitate the electron transfer processes by providing active sites for the reactions and enhancing the effective carbon electrode area.[189] Specifically, the electro-catalytic kinetics are in the order of carboxyl MWNTs > hydroxyl MWNTs > pristine MWNTs.[188] However, functionalization of CNTs must be performed carefully, because significant destruction of the sp2 domain resulted in poor electrochemical
performance.[190] In an alternative way, nitrogen-doped CNT materials have exhibited high electro-catalytic activity in many electrochemical devices.[191] In a recent study, Wang et al. have successfully grown N-CNTs on graphite felt (N-CNT/GF) by a chemical vapor deposition process, and examined their electrocatalytic behavior for RFCs.[192] The results showed that the VO2+/VO2+ couple on the N-CNT/GF electrode remarkably outperformed the widely used graphite felt, and opened up new and wider applications of nitrogen-doped carbon materials. The enriched porous structure of N-CNTs on graphite felt potentially facilitated the diffusion of electrolyte, while the N-doping ameliorated electrode performance.
Several researchers suggested a CNT composite catalyst on carbon substrate for the vanadium-RFC, offering the advantage of their synergistic effect. This has been demonstrated by growing carbon nanofiber/nanotubes (CNF/CNT) on carbon felt[193] or CNT-filled polyphenylene sulfide on graphite.[194] Figure 8 displays an example of a CNF/CNT composite catalyst prepared by thermal decomposition of acetylene gas over Ni catalysts at 700 °C, which demonstrates optimal electro-catalytic properties toward the V2+/V3+ and VO2+/VO2+ redox couples. Moreover, compared to untreated carbon felt electrode, this composite electrode substantially upgraded discharge capacity and energy efficiency of a RFC by ≈64% and by ≈25% at 40 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. This outstanding performance is ascribed to the enhanced surface defect sites of exposed edge plane in CNF and a fast electron transfer rate of in-plane side wall of the CNT as well.

sections.heading: 4.2. Redox Flow Cells Based on Graphene-Related Materials
sections.text:
Exploration of GO modified electrodes shows a unique and intriguing voltammetry response, which is utilized beneficially where oxygenated electro-catalytic reactions are employed.[195,196] Most importantly, GO is generally rich in hydroxyl and carboxyl acid active groups attached on the edges, which possibly provide active sites to boost the vanadium redox reactions.[197] For these reasons, GO have been extensively explored as catalysts
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1600278
P R O G R ES S R EP O R T
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (15 of 21) 1600278wileyonlinelibrary.com
for redox flow reactions in recent years.[198–202] Cui et al.[198] and Skyllas-Kazacos et al.[201] adopted GO sheets to facilitate the electrochemical kinetics towards the V2+/V3+ and VO2+/VO2+ redox couples. However, the poor conductivity of GO restricts the voltage efficiency of the vanadium-RFC. This issue can be mitigated by low-temperature thermal reduction, leading to the partial release of oxygen and better structural integrity. Cui et al. reported that composite electrode of GO and MWNT demonstrated better electro-catalytic redox reversibility towards the positive VO2+/VO2+ couple than either GO nanosheets or MWNTs themselves.[199] Similarly, Yan et. al. reported that 3 wt% GO being added into graphite electrode greatly boosted the electrochemical performance of the vanadium couples.[200] The catalytic mechanism of the GO composite electrode is associated with surface hydroxyl and carboxyl groups. These surface oxygen functional groups on the basal planes and the edge of the GO sheet function as active site to bridge the vanadium transport and catalyze the electron-transfer process.[200]
Reduced graphene oxide (rGO) was considered a favorable electroactive material for RFCs because of high electrical conductivity and presence of trace oxygen groups.[203] The electro-catalytic activity of rGO products is heavily dependent on the composition and type of functional groups on rGO. These characteristics can be facially controlled by manipulating the reduction conditions such as thermal temperature[204] or reduction potential.[205] Blanco and co-workers reported that the electro-catalytic activity of rGO towards VO2+/VO2+ was remarkably enhanced with respect to GO. The rGO reduced at a higher temperature of 1000 °C showed an outstanding electrochemical performance in terms of peak current densities and reversibility, reaching a peak potential separation value of 70 mV. This improvement was attributed to the restoration of sp2 domains of carbon after thermal treatment, which produced a graphene material with a high electrical conductivity and accessible surface area. Alternatively, nitrogen doping in rGO can also efficiently facilitate the reaction kinetics and reversibility of the VO2+/VO2+ redox couple.[206]

sections.heading: 4.3. Redox Flow Cells Based on 3D Nanocarbons
sections.text:
Most flow batteries reported in the literature adopt a flow-by configuration (electrolyte flow parallel to the electrode). Thus, 3D electrodes would outperform 1D and 2D electrodes due to the large surface area, increased active sites, and enriched pores for electrolyte penetration, which result in faster electrochemical reactions and lower polarization at the electrodes.[207] With this consideration, 3D graphite felts have become one of the most successful electrodes in practice for RFCs. In a simi lar way, it is predicted that 3D nanocarbons would surpass their corresponding 1D CNT and 2D graphene components in electro-catalytic performance.[208]
Although 2D rGO has been shown to be a superior vanadium-RFC electrode, its performance is often compromised by agglomeration and restacking of graphene nanosheets. This can be prevented by incorporating metallic iridium (Ir) nanoparticles onto the rGO nanosheets, therefore enhancing the performance in RFC.[209] The Ir-rGO composite could be easily fabricated by simultaneously reducing GO and IrCl3 H2O with the assistance of NaBH4. In a similar report, rGO-supported CuPt3
served as bimetallic catalysts for improving the VO2+/VO2+ redox process.[210] The CuPt3 species acted not only as a buffer to prevent rGO from restacking, but also offered active sites for electrocatalyzing the electrode reactions in vanadium-RFC.

sections.heading: 5. Carbon Nanomaterials for Energy Storage:
sections.text:
Dimensional Impacts
Although these nanocarbons are promising candidates for EES systems, their potential varies substantially, and is sometimes inconsistent in given devices, showing geometry- or dimensiondependent properties as discussed above.
To be specific, fullerenes alone cannot serve as an electrode material or conductive additive for EESs, due to the 0D feature and lacking of long range conductivity. Thus they have found wide applications in energy conversion but barely in energy storage.[119] 1D CNTs have excellent conductivity, rich porosity, and structural flexibility, characteristics that are being recognized as essential components of high power EES systems where the CNTs serve as conductive addition.[47] However, the high-aspect-ratio and 1D nature of CNTs makes them difficult to controllably assemble nanotubes into complex EES devices. Additionally, the strong tendency to form bundles also presents a significant challenge for CNT application in electrochemical devices. Similarly, 2D graphene has extraordinary properties of strength, flexibility, and electrical conductivity. These unique attributes have generated enormous interest and attention in EESs with profitable outcomes compared with current devices. More importantly, they can offer more surface active sites compared with CNTs, which hold more electroactive particles and raise their loading. However, the large surface area is frequently lost due to folding, stacking, and wrinkling of graphene sheets, while the excellent conductivity is often compromised by absorbed impurities and defects. These drawbacks are strongly related to the 2D nature of the structure.
In contrast, the 3D nanocarbons (3D CNT, graphene, or CNT/graphene hybrid) can address the energy and power issues simultaneously due to their unique structure and physical characteristics. Figure 9 shows a typical 3D electrode architecture consisting of 3D CNT and graphene arrays, which serve as excellent conductive substrates to improve both energy and power densities of EES. In such 3D systems, bundling or folding of nanocarbons can be largely avoided, thus a higher surface area and more active sites can be achieved. The 3D electrodes also allow electrolyte infusion and access of ions to the electroactive component and facilitate Li ion diffusion along the axis direction. Meanwhile, the intimate contact between nanocarbon and the current collector provides a low resistance pathway, allowing for effective connectivity throughout the electrode.[82] In addition, the 3D architecture helps provide homogeneous electrochemical accessibility and uniform current distribution, which thus reduces mechanical stresses during repeated cycling. Moreover, the electrode is continuous and porous, thus the space within the electrode can accommodate large volume changes during charge and discharge.[79] Last but not least, no extra conductive agent and binder are needed. Therefore, a 3D electrode has not only a high areal energy capacity, but also much improved power performance and cycle

life.[122,211] Of course, synthesis and scaling-up feasibility of such 3D nanocarbons are major issues currently and therefore urgently necessitate the advancement of synthetic technologies.
The advantages of 3D nanocarbons over corresponding 1D and 2D materials are particularly envisaged in SC fields, where rapid electron and ion nobilities are generally required.[212,213] Figure 10 gives examples for 3D nanocarbon materials including 3D CNT (Figure 10A), 3D graphene (Figure 10B), and 3D CNT/ graphene hybrid (Figure 10C) for SC application. The CNT/ NiCo2O4 core/shell structure delivers a capacitance of 694 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, and retains 82% of capacitance at 20 A g−1, which is amongst the best rate capability ever reported for NiCo2O4.[146] In the case of 3D NiO-graphene, a full-cell based on the hierarchical materials is realized with an energy density of 138 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 5.25 kW kg−1, which is much superior to commercial ones as well as reported devices in asymmetric capacitors of NiO.[214] SCs based on 3D RuO2/CNT/ graphene hybrid foams show superior gravimetric and areal capacitive performance (specific capacitance: 502.78 F g−1, areal capacitance: 1.11 F cm−2). This leads to an exceptionally high energy density of 39.28 Wh kg−1 and power density of 128.01 kW kg−1.[147] Clearly, 3D nanocarbon materials offer an opportunity to increase both energy and power densities in one device.

sections.heading: 6. Summary and Prospects
sections.text:
EES is becoming increasingly critical in our daily life. Efficient utilization of the clean renewable energy and adaption
of low-emission EVs require high-energy, high-power, durable storage devices at an affordable cost. Though there has been ongoing progress and remarkable success in portable systems, current LIBs and SCs are limited by severe performance challenges of electrode materials in terms of low energy and power density as well as short durability. Owing to their unique structure and properties,[215] various carbon nanomaterials have been shown to be great possible alternatives to overcome these problems and exhibit great potential in various EES strategies.
Carbon nanomaterials and their associated derivatives have been explored as either electrode materials or electrode additives for LIBs. 1D CNTs and 2D graphene have demonstrated favorable anode properties, exhibiting a high capacity level (400–1000 mAh g−1) and robust rate capability (>10 C). Further upgrades in their electrochemical performance might rely on ordered 3D assemblies such as aligned arrays, uniform foams, and pillared hybrids. These assemblies can boost energy, rate performance, and cyclability of carbon nanomaterials for LIBs. Nanostructured carbons may also act as excellent conductive additives for common electrode materials, providing higher electron mobility with a lower percolation threshold. Carbon nanomaterialssupported active materials can be prepared by simple mixing process, but preferentially through in situ pathways to warrant robust interaction. Nanocarbons enriched with oxygen-containing groups can facilitate template-directed nucleation and growth of active materials. Therefore the functionalization of carbon nanomaterials is important to eventually achieve high EES performance.
Carbon nanomaterials are particularly attractive for SC applications because of their intrinsic properties such as high

conductivity and charge transport capability. The extremely high specific surface area (1315 and 2630 m2 g−1 for SWNTs and single-layer graphene, respectively) make single-layered nanocarbons promising materials for double-layer ion adsorption/desorption. However, the excellent properties of carbon nanomaterials will not easily translate to medium- and largescale devices if thin-film and/or low-density electrodes are used.[216] In order to further increase the specific capacitance of SCs, 3D nanocarbons and hybrids have been designed and demonstrated improved energy and power densities. Despite numerous advantages and novel functionality that 3D carbon nanomaterials provide, significant challenges remain before they become commercially viable.
1D CNTs, 2D graphene and their 3D architecture have been successfully utilized to facilitate the oxygenated electro-catalytic reactions occurring in RFC. Despite the reported increased electrochemical activities with nanocarbon electrodes, whether those improvements can be translated into RFC cell performance remains unknown. Nevertheless, it is believed that the surface properties and functional groups of the nanocarbon electrodes are crucial to the redox process. In this regard, more efforts are needed in this field.
With continuing growth of production capability and declining cost, CNT-improved rechargeable Li batteries have reached the commercial market. CNT-intensified activated carbons are also appearing to hit the SCs market. This is just an initiative and the expansion of carbon nanomaterial applications for energy storage systems is surely coming. The utilization of diverse carbon nanomaterials and 3D nanocarbon
in particular in various EES systems has proven to be an intriguing and profitable research topic. However, the success of this research heavily relies on advancing the production of these nanomaterials in an efficient way, which involves mass productivity, affordable cost, and effective separation and dispersion. Certainly, this prerequisite requires advanced synthetic technology, sophisticated facilities, and great effort as well. Moreover, a deep understanding of the interaction between carbon nanomaterials and active electrodes will revolutionize the way through which electrodes are engineered and devices constructed. Given time and effort devoted to these studies, the massive use of carbon nanomaterials in EES can be clearly envisaged in the near future.

referenceMentions.context: Fullerene, carbon nanotube (CNT),[2,3] and graphene[4] are well known zero-, one- and two- dimensional (0D, 1D, 2D) carbon nanomaterials.

CNTs have a tubular structure, and show a much high lengthto-diameter ratio, typically several nanometers in diameter and many micrometers in length.[2,3] Ultralong CNTs up to 550 mm have been produced recently with a floating chemical vapor deposition process.
[5] Graphene can be fabricated by chemical or electrochemical reduction of graphene oxide (GO).[30] The product is usually called reduced graphene oxide (rGO).

In addition, the surge in varied electric vehicles requires sufficient and efficient energy storage with higher energy and power density.[45] It is estimated that there were over 380 000 highwaycapable EVs and utilities worldwide by the end of 2013, up from more than 180 000 units in 2012.

The capacity of CNTs can be further increased to 1000 mAh g−1, if nanotubes are subjected to chemical treatments such as chemical etching and nitrogen doping.[52,53] These treatments introduce vast defects in the wall of nanotubes, which provide additional sites for Li ion adsorption and contribute to capacity improvement.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201600278 In spite of an ongoing advancement, current popular EES systems including Li-ion batteries (LIBs), supercapacitors (SCs), and redox flow cells (RFCs) are limited by severe performance challenges of electrode materials in terms of low energy and power density as well as short durability. To mitigate the issues, carbon nanomaterials could be introduced to these EES systems, taking advantage of their unique geometry, excellent conductivity, large surface area, and intrinsic flexibility. Numerous carbon nanomaterial based EES systems, where carbon nanomaterials are adopted as either conducting additive or active electrode, have been developed and demonstrated appealing energy and power features. With the capability to enhance the structural and electrochemical properties of electrodes, carbon nanomaterials and their derivatives offer a wide range of possibilities to design advanced EES devices that can meet our growing energy and power demands in the future. A number of reviews have been published in the past few years on the application of carbon nanomaterials in EES.[5–8] However, this area is so active and new works accumulate very quickly. Therefore, it is helpful to update the new designs and outcomes. This progress report will summarize the most exciting recent (from the year 2010 onwards) advances in the application of carbon nanomaterials with different dimensions, i.e., 0D fullerene, 1D CNT, 2D graphene, and 3D assemblies of CNT and graphene, in EES systems, and highlight the new trends in the field. Besides the repetitively reviewed LIBs and SCs, this work will also deal with another important system, the RFC, which has been rejuvenated recently and is becoming increasingly vital for large scale energy storage. The recent EES applications of carbon nanomaterials will be discussed based on their dimensions.
